post_text: Starting Thursday, September 17th, Grab N' Go Meals picked up will also include meals for the weekend! Recently, TDA allowed districts to continue serving meals for free to children in the community. Along with that, DeSoto ISD now can hand out weekend meals for a limited time. So, until further notice, every Thursday Meal Distribution will include the meals for Thursday-Sunday.

post_text:
This year Chef Appreciation Week takes on special significance as the people behind the food became the heroes behind the food. Across all lines of business, from healthcare and education to B&I and entertainment, the women and men in foodservice quickly adapted to serve on the front lines, feeding and caring for their local communities during this challenging time. We are incredibly grateful for their extraordinary dedication, creativity, and passion to nourish and connect us through thoughtfully prepared, delicious food, meal after meal.

We want to thank Chef Jesse Ortiz Jr. for all his dedication to the DeSoto ISD Child Nutrition Program during the COVID-19 Pandemic. Chef Jesse is the District Executive Chef for Chartwells K12 and takes pride in making sure the students in DeSoto ISD are served balanced and delicious meals even in times of uncertainty. #HeroesBehindTheFood #BeyondtheCafeteria #Chartwells

post_text:
School is back in session, but we still need your participation with the 2020 U.S. Census. Your input will help your community and family get the funds required for the next 10 years. It’s time to make a difference in your future. Contribute today. Go to 2020Census.gov or call 844.330.2020 and add to the count.

If you haven’t taken the census, it’s not too late. Get counted so your voice can impact the way federal funds are distributed within your community for the next 10 years. The census is quick and easy. Go to 2020Census.gov or call 844.330.2020 and get counted.

While your kids are remote learning, you can take the census with no social interaction. Go to 2020Census.gov or call 844.330.2020 and add to the count to help fund your community’s needed services. Get counted today!

post_text: Pick up your grab & go meals from any distribution site for a chance to win a laptop! For the month of September, every time you pick up meals, your Student ID number is entered into a drawing. So the more meals you pick up, the more chances you have to win! The winner will be randomly drawn Friday, October 2nd, 2020 and will be contacted by a Chartwells Team Member in the Child Nutrition Office. #ChartwellsK12 #beyondthecafeteria #desotostrong #desotograbandgomeals

post_text:
DeSoto ISD PTA’s are here to support every child’s potential! This is an opportunity for all parents and caregivers to be engaged in their child’s education.

How Can You PTA?
Please take a few minutes to respond to our brief DeSoto ISD PTA survey https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScOmC8TtTl3j1IDmd8GD4iJCNcX9RjBhhfBVf8khBn-Hx6VNw/viewform

PTA is no longer a noun. It’s a verb –it’s an action plan working to support your child’s success.
Registration for PTA membership for the 2020-2021 school year opened on August 3 and you can sign up at https://www.joinpta.org/.

For more information, contact rubyyoungespta@gmail.com.

post_text:
When matters of concern arise in our community, we desire to address those concerns as directly as possible.

My colleagues and I on the DeSoto Independent School District Board have been made aware of past social media posts shared to the personal social media account of Acting Superintendent Dr. Don Hooper whose hiring as a consultant was approved by the Board at the recommendation of the district’s former superintendent.

DeSoto ISD prides itself on its diverse school community and does not support, condone or excuse the rhetoric of the reposted content. In addressing the matter, Dr. Hooper has apologized for the content and his decision to share the content.

Read more of Board President Karen Daniel's letter here: http://www.desotoisd.org/board_of_trustees/news__updates___statements/acting_superintendent_social_media

The Promise Pledge is officially open and we are so excited to support The Class of 2021 with their postsecondary journey. Click the link to view a step-by-step screenshot guide for the Pledge. This is just the first step of completing the Dallas County Promise steps to secure this amazing opportunity!

post_text:
A special message from Dr. D'Andre Weaver:

Dear DeSoto,

My earliest, fondest memories of my grandmother, Alberta Weaver, occurred in our home in Chicago. It was the home that she purchased almost 50 years ago after saving a portion of her bi-weekly paycheck in a shoebox, hidden under a floorboard in a small apartment located in one of the notoriously unsafe “projects” in Chicago. My grandmother was the first in her family to own a home and she earned the money working the night shift at R. R. Donnelley manually assembling advertisement catalogues. She usually returned home about 7:30 AM and spent the next several hours watching me while my mother went to work. It was during our time together that she would affirm how special I was and how one day, I would “be somebody.”

Read more here: http://desotoisd.org/about_de_soto_i_s_d/superintendent/news_and_updates/8_31_2020_a_message_from_dr__d__andre_weaver

Dear DeSoto,

My earliest, fondest memories of my grandmother, Alberta Weaver, occurred in our home in Chicago. It was the home that she purchased almost 50 years ago after saving a portion of her bi-weekly paycheck in a shoebox, hidden under a floorboard in a small apartment located in one of the notoriously unsafe “projects” in Chicago. My grandmother was the first in her family to own a home and she earned the money working the night shift at R. R. Donnelley manually assembling advertisement catalogues. She usually returned home about 7:30 AM and spent the next several hours watching me while my mother went to work. As a Board, we understand your concerns regarding the recent news that we accepted the voluntary resignation of Dr. D’Andre J. Weaver as superintendent of DeSoto ISD.

Please know that, as a Board, we are committed to working with administration to ensure that teachers are prepared and ready to lead virtual instruction and that students have the support and resources needed to thrive this school year.

It is our goal to move away from the distraction of adult issues and reposition our collective focus back on meeting the needs of our students, teachers, families, and community.

Read more:
http://www.desotoisd.org/board_of_trustees/news__updates___statements/weaver_resignation

shared_text:
DeSoto ISD added 19 new photos — at DeSoto High School.
August 21 at 5:23 PM · DeSoto, TX ·

Although the school year will begin after Labor Day, 14 DeSoto High School student athletic trainers arose early Thursday morning to serve their community with the North Texas Food Bank. Clad in black and white or in their DeSoto gear, these students masked up to facilitate the operations of the third DeSoto Food Bank Distribution Day held this season at DeSoto High School.

From loading the vehicles with food boxes and helping with guest hospitality to managing the traffic flow and intake, the students worked alongside the North Texas Food Bank staff and Dr. David Young, DHS athletic trainer, to serve approximately 450 families in the space of three hours.

The DeSoto ISD Board of Trustees and administration invite the school community to participate in the Thursday, August 20, 2020 Public Hearing regarding the published findings of the district’s recent TEA investigation.

While all who have pre-registered will be permitted to share comments in a live-streamed, virtual forum, the district would like to inform the public of the rules of engagement for this meeting.

post_text:
Like a market on wheels, the North Texas Food Bank's Mobile Pantry program is a traveling pantry that delivers nutritious food, including fresh produce and refrigerated items, directly to communities with high need. NTFB staff and host site volunteers unload, set up and distribute food directly to clients in a parking lot.

For the August 20, 2020 DeSoto Distribution Day at DeSoto High School (Eagle Stadium) at 700 Eagle Drive, we were informed that we needed a few more volunteers to help from 7:30 A.M. to 11:30 A.M., to help with check- in, manage the line, distribute food boxes and more. If you know someone who can support the NTFB effort, please share this message and link with them.

Interested volunteers must register with the food bank via the link below, so they will know all of the roles, requirements, and expectations for volunteering.
Here is a link for each volunteer to sign up: https://ntfb.volunteerhub.com/event/index/12402652

Thanks for your support of the North Texas Food Bank’s effort to serve the DeSoto Community.

text:
Following the publication of the Texas Education Agency’s final report, the DeSoto ISD has been required to host a public hearing.

In response to this requirement, a Special Called Meeting and Public Hearing on SAI conducted by the TEA of the Board of Trustees of DeSoto ISD will be held at 6 p.m. on August 20, 2020.

Learn more and register to speak at the virtual event here: http://ow.ly/FkyO50B2Fqp

post_text:
A Special Called Meeting and Public Hearing on SAI conducted by the Texas Education Agency of the Board of Trustees of DeSoto Independent School District will be held on August 20, 2020, beginning at 6 PM.

The Board will conduct a public hearing as required by the Texas Education Agency at 7 PM.

Due to health and safety concerns related to the COVID-19 coronavirus, this meeting will be conducted by videoconference or telephone call. At least a quorum of the board will be participating by videoconference or telephone call in accordance with the provisions of Sections
551.125 or 551.127 of the Texas Government Code that has not been suspended by order of the governor.

In order to speak at the Aug. 20 public hearing, those interested must pre-register. Pre-registration information will be published tomorrow, August 18, 2020.

Those interested can access the meeting via DeSoto ISD website:http://desotoisdtx.swagit.com/live.
text:
A Special Called Meeting and Public Hearing on SAI conducted by the Texas Education Agency of the Board of Trustees of DeSoto Independent School District will be held on August 20, 2020, beginning at 6 PM.

Due to health and safety concerns related to the COVID-19 coronavirus, this meeting will be conducted by videoconference or telephone call. At least a quorum of the board will be participating by videoconference or telephone call in accordance with the provisions of Sections
551.125 or 551.127 of the Texas Government Code that has not been suspended by order of the governor.

In order to speak at the Aug. 20 public hearing, those interested must pre-register. Pre-registration information will be published tomorrow, August 18, 2020.

post_text:
Basado en la guía de salud local y nuestro monitoreo de las reaperturas del distrito escolar en otras áreas, DeSoto ISD ha modificado el Plan de reapertura del 8 de septiembre de 2020 del distrito de la siguiente manera:

El 8 de septiembre, todos los estudiantes de DeSoto ISD comenzarán las primeras cuatro semanas de clases a través del aprendizaje supervisado en el hogar a través de la plataforma de aprendizaje Anytime, Anywhere hasta el 2 de octubre de 2020. Durante este período, el distrito no ofrecerá la opción de aprendizaje supervisado por el campus como como resultado de las tendencias recientes relacionadas con los casos de COVID-19 en el condado de Dallas.

post_text:
Based on local health guidance and our monitoring of school district re-openings in other areas, DeSoto ISD has modified the district’s September 8, 2020, Reopening Plan as follows:

On September 8, all DeSoto ISD students will begin the first four weeks of school via home-supervised learning through the Anytime, Anywhere Learning platform through October 2, 2020. During this period, the district will not offer the campus-supervised learning option as a result of recent trends related to COVID-19 cases in Dallas County.

Read more: http://ow.ly/DWnx50AYI4N

post_text: DeSoto East Middle School Choir Director and campus Teacher of the year Jamal Walker is a history maker! Walker is one of six hand-picked choristers featured on CBS Sunday Morning who participated in the largest virtual choir ever assembled. Simply named Eric Whitacre's Virtual Choir 6, after its Grammy-award winning conductor and composer, the choir is comprised of 17,572 participants representing 129 countries. Read more about Walker's historic choir experience during COVID-19 at https://bit.ly/2BqsbVG.

post_text:
The health of our school community continues to be our priority as we prepare for the start of school. With this in mind, DeSoto ISD joins with other Best Southwest School Districts and intends to delay the start of school to follow the Labor Day weekend - Tuesday, Sept. 8, 2020. Each school district plans to take to their respective Board of Trustees a calendar that reflects school starting after Labor Day.
Read more: http://www.desotoisd.org/cms/One.aspx?portalId=165774&pageId=24117842

post_text: Tips and resources to surviving COVID-19 from the City of DeSoto, Texas - City Hall
shared_text:
City of DeSoto, Texas - City Hall
July 9 at 10:45 AM ·

As the physical threat from Coronavirus continues in our community, so too does the strain on our individual resources. That is why we are reposting the "DeSoto Together" COVID-19 Resource Document for DeSoto Residents. It was developed by the Target Populations Subcommittee of the DeSoto Economic Recovery Advisory Task Force. Pastor Marcus D. King is Chair of the subcommittee and he and his team assembled a great document that can be viewed below. Or visit our website for downloadable copies of the flyer and poster:
Flyer Size 10 x 13 Version: https://www.ci.desoto.tx.us/DocumentCenter/View/17465/DeSoto_Together_flyer_10x15

Poster Size 20 x 30 Version: https://www.ci.desoto.tx.us/DocumentCenter/View/17466/DeSoto_Together_poster_20x30

post_text:
Chartwells is bringing their educational Discovery Kitchen to your kitchen! Even though we are apart, together, we can still get hands-on with a healthy snack recipe and learn about the ingredients we are trying. On Thursday, July 9th, when you stop by a meal distribution site and pick up your meals, you will also get a Discovery Kitchen at Home bag with all the ingredients needed to put the recipe together. Once you have the ingredients you can follow along here with the Discovery Kitchen video!
As a friendly reminder, the meal distribution sites are Amber Terrace DDECA, Frank D. Moates Elementary, The Meadows Elementary, or DeSoto High School- Freshman Campus.

Still want to participate but unable to pick up an ingredient bag? Follow the recipe below.

Recipe makes 10 energy bites
1/2 Cup: Sunflower Seed Butter OR Peanut Butter
1 TSP: Vanilla Extract
1/4 Cup: Graham Crackers- Crushed
1/3 Cup: Honey
1 Cup: Quick Oats
1/2 Cup: Craisins OR Raisins- Chopped

https://youtu.be/6FO4RDdIEsY

As a district of the community, it is our goal to equip our Eagles to soar for the 2020-2021 school year!

This year, DeSoto ISD will host a virtual back to school fair with a drive-thru school supply pick-up. While maintaining social distancing, we will continue to support students to ensure that they are academically prepared.

The 2020-2021 Back to School Fair will take place from 9 am to noon, Saturday, August 15, 2020, at the DeSoto High School located at 600 Eagle Dr., DeSoto, TX 75115.

Registration for the event will take place through the student online enrollment process.

For those interested in supporting DeSoto ISD as we prepare for the upcoming school year, there are opportunities to donate materials for students and sponsorships.

For more information, visit www.DeSotoISD.org/BackToSchoolFair

post_text:
As we approach the start of the 2020-2021 school year, our families may have questions about what school will look like for the upcoming academic year. DeSoto ISD will utilize the Anytime, Anywhere Learning (AAL) system to guide education for our students this fall through three options - Home-Supervised Learning, Campus-Supervised Learning or Hybrid Learning - designed to provide choice and support for our families and their scholars.

DeSoto ISD is excited to support educational choice and flexibility for our families. To help us start planning for a successful school year, please complete this survey: https://form.jotform.com/201759200397052

UPDATE: Due to rainy weather, the balloon release for Jermaine "JJ" Jackson has been rescheduled to 6 p.m. Wednesday, June 24, 2020.
_______________________________________________
A balloon release ceremony for West Middle School student
Jermaine “JJ” Jackson will be held at 6 pm, Tuesday, June 23, 2020, on the DeSoto West Middle School football field.

Those attending are asked to bring blue balloons to release in his honor and to practice social distancing.

DeSoto ISD extends thoughts and prayers to JJ’s family, friends, teachers, coaches and all who knew this incredible young person during this time.

post_text:
On June 19, 1865, two years after President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation, Gen. Gordon Granger and Union troops arrived in Galveston, TX and announced the ending of slavery in Texas and the United States.

Learn more about the history of Juneteenth here: http://ow.ly/SS7V50AblAj

post_text:
This Administration has been intentional about working with integrity and transparency so that the District can regain the trust of the community. We see our relationship (which includes communication and transparency) with our Board of Trustees as very important in our ability to truly improve as a District.

We understand that there has been community interest and concern regarding recent Board action to approve a purchase of service with reDesignU. We want to be clear that nothing illegal nor unethical occurred and are providing the following information to provide context to clarify what occurred and why.

Read more: http://www.desotoisd.org/board_of_trustees/board_action_regarding_re_design

DeSoto ISD Families are invited to the Summer Book Clubs Virtual Kick Off! Join us on Tuesday, June 16, 2020 at 6:30 p.m. via Zoom as we discuss the summer book lists, book-related activities, and upcoming book discussions. Registration is required to join the event: visit https://bit.ly/DeISDBookClubs to sign up today!

If you are interested in donating books for our book club readers, please contact us at info@desotoisd.org. View the complete list at https://bit.ly/SummerWonder.

post_text:
As an extension of the Anytime, Anywhere Learning, the Curriculum Department presents self-paced summer learning activities for PK-12 that are designed to enhance background knowledge in a fun and informal way. The activities are optional and will not be submitted for grading. Students completing learning tasks should be celebrated throughout the summer. Special badges will be awarded at the beginning of the school year. Siblings in different grades are welcomed to work together.

DeSoto ISD will not offer a traditional summer school. Any student that received an Incomplete (I), must complete the End of Year Culminating Performance Assessment (CPA) projects to receive a Pass (P) indicating the student has demonstrated proficiency of content for the term.

Learn more: www.DeSotoISD.org/SummerLearning

post_text: DeSoto ISD and DeSoto High School will partner with the North Texas Food Bank (NTFB) to distribute kitted food boxes to the members of our community through a low-touch distribution model on Tuesday, June 2. All food distribution will be on a first-come, first-serve basis and should be a mix of fresh food and shelf-stable items. To receive food, visitors must be in a vehicle. No proof of identification is necessary and this is open to all members of the community. All cars will enter through the stadium entrance and navigate as directed, please share with others in the community and let’s all help each other.

post_text:
Congratulations to the Class of 2020! Over the past couple of weeks, seniors have submitted their photos and videos revealing where they will attend college as a way to participate in Decision Season! We have also highlighted students who have gone above and beyond during their time at DeSoto High School.

Traditionally, we would host Academic Signing Day to provide seniors with an opportunity to display where they will attend in the Fall based on their scholarship dollars, however, we had to improvise and switch up the celebration this year! As a result, we will wrap-up our Decision Season by showcasing the seniors who have received scholarships, both academic and athletic!

Seniors were asked to submit their scholarship offers to us for the creation of this presentation. Some seniors college decisions may differ from the scholarships displayed, however, they have received other financial aid such as grants and others may still be undecided.

Either way, we are pleased to announce that the Class of 2020 received over $16 million dollars in scholarships!
text:
Congratulations to the Class of 2020! Over the past couple of weeks, seniors have submitted their photos and videos revealing where they will attend college as a way to participate in Decision Season! We have also highlighted students who have gone above and beyond during their time at DeSoto High School.

Traditionally, we would host Academic Signing Day to provide seniors with an opportunity to display where they will attend in the Fall based on their scholarship dollars, however, we had to improvise and switch up the celebration this year! As a result, we will wrap-up our Decision Season by showcasing the seniors who have received scholarships, both academic and athletic!

Seniors were asked to submit their scholarship offers to us for the creation of this presentation. Some seniors college decisions may differ from the scholarships displayed, however, they have received other financial aid such as grants and others may still be undecided.

Either way, we are pleased to announce that the Class of 2020 received over $16 million dollars in scholarships!

post_text: As we celebrate Memorial Day on Monday, May 25th, remember that there will be no meal distribution that day. When you pick up meals on Thursday, May 21st, you will receive breakfast, lunch, and dinner for Thursday-Monday. Meal distribution will resume on Tuesday, May 26th. It is on Tuesday that you will receive your meals for Tuesday/Wednesday and Thursday distribution will be available as normal. The Chartwells Team with DeSoto ISD Child Nutrition wishes you a wonderful Memorial Day!
text: As we celebrate Memorial Day on Monday, May 25th, remember that there will be no meal distribution that day. When you pick up meals on Thursday, May 21st, you will receive breakfast, lunch, and dinner for Thursday-Monday. Meal distribution will resume on Tuesday, May 26th. It is on Tuesday that you will receive your meals for Tuesday/Wednesday and Thursday distribution will be available as normal. The Chartwells Team with DeSoto ISD Child Nutrition wishes you a wonderful Memorial Day!

post_text: Class of 2020, today is about you! Starting at 1, from Westmoreland entrance heading north from Parkerville. Decorate your car, put on your class T-shirt or cap and gown and come pick up your yard sign. Seniors and sponsors only!

post_text:
The virtual graduation will be live streamed, only program participants will be present on site. The mini-ceremony on the 27th is for specifically invited students with special accommodations requirements, class officers and top 10. The remaining members of the class will be invited on the 28th in alpha order.

A-F (9:00 - 9:45)
G-L (10:00 - 10:45)
M-O (11:00 - 11:45)
P-S (12:00 - 12:45)
T-Z (1:00 - 1:45)
Graduates and family members will join ONE day, either the 27th or 28th.

If students choose not to participate, diplomas can be picked up on the 29th or will be mailed after June 1.

Jalen Jackson was live in Adopt a Senior student 2020 Desoto ISD.

post_text: Class of 2020 - today is the day the City of DeSoto salutes you!! From 1 to 4 pm TODAY, drive through to pick up your new congratulations yard signs sponsored by the City of DeSoto, Texas - City Hall, DeSoto Police Department, DeSoto Police Clergy & Community and Methodist Charlton Medical Center! Wear your class shirt or cap and gown if you like! FOR TRAFFIC CONTROL AND TO ENSURE SOCIAL DISTANCING, ONLY SENIORS AND SPONSORS WILL BE ALLOWED ON THE PARKING LOT. Beginning at 1 pm continuing through 4 pm. Enter DeSoto High School by heading north on Westmoreland from Parkerville, then follow the signs. Congratulations Class of 2020!

post_text: May is Mental Health Awareness month and the week of May 18 - May 22 is Mental Health Awareness Week. Millions of Americans are affected by mental health conditions every year. Having a mental illness can make it challenging to live in everyday life. Take a look at some of the ways mental illness can impact lives. https://www.nami.org/NAMI/media/NAMI-Media/Infographics/NAMI-Impact-Ripple-Effect-FINAL.pdf

post_text: As a community service project, the McCowan Middle School JROTC led by Sgt.Tyrone Johnson donated 842 lbs. of food to the DeSoto Food Pantry. Their effort provided enough food to support 280 families. It was a pleasure to have The Honorable DeSoto Mayor Curtistene McCowan, the campus' namesake, onsite to support the donation.

post_text:
Culminating Performance Assessment videos will roll daily on the City of DeSoto’s Public Access Channel until 7 pm on a loop.

Families and students can access the broadcast on either Spectrum (Channel 16), or AT&T Uverse (Channel 99). If your cable provider does not offer the public access channel, families can contact their cable provider for assistance in adding the channel to your available content. Families can also watch live online at http://www.desototexas.gov/854/DeSoto-Cable-TV .

post_text: DeSoto ISD is hosting Journeys Beyond Horizons: A Virtual Gifted and Talented Showcase to provide an opportunity for students who receive GT programming to present projects of their choice to an audience. This is an optional experience for GT students. Students can submit a 2-5 minute video for the showcase. Parents/Legal Guardians must register to submit their child's video at https://bit.ly/DeISDGTShowcase. The deadline for submissions is May 21, 2020.

post_text:
Dinner is now included with all meals! As Monday pickups will include breakfast, lunch, and dinners for Monday-Wednesday, and Thursday pickups will include breakfast, lunch, and dinners for Thursday-Sunday.

In those meals, you will find one hot item for that day’s lunch for you to enjoy right away. The remaining meals will either be shelf-stable items or meals that require immediate refrigeration.

Heating instructions are included for appropriate meals inside packaging. Pickups at all locations take place from 9 AM-1 PM.
text:
Dinner is now included with all meals! As Monday pickups will include breakfast, lunch, and dinners for Monday-Wednesday, and Thursday pickups will include breakfast, lunch, and dinners for Thursday-Sunday.

In those meals, you will find one hot item for that day’s lunch for you to enjoy right away. The remaining meals will either be shelf-stable items or meals that require immediate refrigeration.

Heating instructions are included for appropriate meals inside packaging. Pickups at all locations take place from 9 AM-1 PM.

The DeSoto High School Girls Basketball program had an impressive 2019-2020 season ending with three of the players being ranked in ESPN’s Class of 2022 HoopGurlz Recruiting Rankings – Super 60. 🏀

Published by the sports network’s female-focused platform, espnW in late April, DeSoto Forward, Sa’Mayah Smith placed #15 on the list. While Forward Amina Muhammad ranked #24 and Wing Ayanna Thompson ranked at #57.

http://www.desotoisd.org/news/what_s_new/d_h_s_girls_basketball_receive_national_attention

May 4th kicks off Teacher Appreciation Week 2020!! What better way to celebrate than announcing our campus Teachers of the Year? DeSoto ISD would like to congratulate the following teachers on being named Teacher of the Year at their respective campuses:

Keontaye Kelly-James – Amber Terrace
Araceli Olvera – Cockrell Hill
Brenda Murphy – Frank Moates
John Rhodes – Katherine Johnson
Sabrina Mayberry – Ruby Young
Kyria Moore – The Meadows
Amber Lowe-Harris - Woodridge
Jamal Walker – East Middle
Dexter Dotson – McCowan Middle
Alisha Garrett – West Middle
Vinita Hegwood – DeSoto High
Jamee Cox – DAEP

Tune in here on the District’s Facebook page daily at 1pm to view videos from our Teacher of the Year recipients leading up to the big announcement of our Elementary-level and Secondary-level Teacher of the Year recipients.

shared_text:
DeSoto ISD added 6 new photos.
May 1 at 9:54 AM ·

During this celebration of #SchoolLunchHeroDay, we want to share a little insight on a few of our child nutrition staff who have been diligently working on the frontlines in the community to meet the needs of students and their families!
text:
DeSoto ISD added 6 new photos.
May 1 at 9:54 AM ·

During this celebration of #SchoolLunchHeroDay, we want to share a little insight on a few of our child nutrition staff who have been diligently working on the frontlines in the community to meet the needs of students and their families!

post_text: Our DeSoto ISD Child Nutrition Department and Chartwells team are true heroes. Since the start of the Grab & Go meal services, the team has served over 84,000 meals to students & families during the COVID-19 pandemic. Please join us in celebrating School Lunch Hero Day by thanking these hard-working individuals.
text: Our DeSoto ISD Child Nutrition Department and Chartwells team are true heroes. Since the start of the Grab & Go meal services, the team has served over 84,000 meals to students & families during the COVID-19 pandemic. Please join us in celebrating School Lunch Hero Day by thanking these hard-working individuals.

post_text:
Hero is defined in the dictionary by a person noted for courageous acts or nobility of character. There are a lot of Heroes in the community, but we want to specifically recognize the Chartwells and DeSoto ISD Child Nutrition Team for being on the front line serving meals to our students during the Covid-19 Crisis.

Friday, May 1st is recognized as National School Lunch Hero Day and we want to extend our sincerest gratitude and encourage the community to thank these hard working heroes! If you frequent one of the meal sites, say thank you, honk your horn, anything to recognize them for their work during these times. Thank You Ladies and Gentlemen, we appreciate you!
text:
Hero is defined in the dictionary by a person noted for courageous acts or nobility of character. There are a lot of Heroes in the community, but we want to specifically recognize the Chartwells and DeSoto ISD Child Nutrition Team for being on the front line serving meals to our students during the Covid-19 Crisis.

Friday, May 1st is recognized as National School Lunch Hero Day and we want to extend our sincerest gratitude and encourage the community to thank these hard working heroes! If you frequent one of the meal sites, say thank you, honk your horn, anything to recognize them for their work during these times. Thank You Ladies and Gentlemen, we appreciate you!

post_text: Anytime, Anywhere Learning is more than a learning plan, it’s the future of learning in DeSoto ISD.
text: Anytime, Anywhere Learning is more than a learning plan, it’s the future of learning in DeSoto ISD.

post_text:
Like many school systems across the country, when executive orders were issued to close schools, DeSoto Independent School District leaders worked to solve the problem of how to provide a continuation of learning that didn’t overwhelm students and families in the midst of a public crisis.

In response, the district created a centralized distance learning plan that became the foundation and catalyst for its successor the Anytime, Anywhere Learning initiative designed and implemented via virtual meetings and training spearheaded by the DeSoto ISD Teaching, Learning and Leadership Division.

Read More: http://www.desotoisd.org/news/what_s_new/tech_expansion_
shared_text:
DESOTOISD.ORG
www.desotoisd.org

The third installment of the DeSoto ISD Town Hall Tuesdays at Noon series will take place via Zoom on April 21. The upcoming mid-day virtual dialogue will focus on physical and emotional wellness during the COVID-19 public health crisis to be followed by the fourth and last installment which will focus on the student perspective amid their adjustments to COVID-19 on April 28.

All members of the DeSoto ISD school community are welcome to participate in the virtual town hall series sessions and can submit questions for our guest medical experts to be addressed during the Zoom meeting. Information relevant to meeting access will be shared with parents of DeSoto ISD students via School Messenger.

Submit questions here: http://ow.ly/rn0M50zgoS2

post_text:
Due to health and safety concerns related to COVID-19, DeSoto ISD Board Meetings are conducted by videoconference and/or telephone. At least a quorum of the board will be participating by videoconference or telephone in accordance with the provisions of Sections 551.125 or 551.127 of the Texas Government Code that have not been suspended by order of the governor.

In order to facilitate Citizens’ Comments, we are asking that citizens submit their comments via a web-based form at least 2 hours before the start of the Board Meeting (whichever Board Meeting in which they wish to “address” the Board)

During the Board Meeting, the comments will be read aloud and recorded. In addition, trustees will receive a copy of all comments.

Please click the link to complete the DeSoto ISD Board Meeting Citizen Comments Form: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdDucQDLU6gox-5D5K-uCwpvCvm0V_I6Xg5enlqduNQjKO-Dw/viewform

post_text:
Due to the district’s holiday closure, no Grab and Go Meals will be served Friday, April 10 nor Monday, April 13.

As noted, that the 75115 zip code is among the highest in the DFW area experiencing confirmed cases of COVID-19, we want to minimize the number of times our students and families are leaving their homes to access district-provided meals. We hope that this reduction will assist the county in its effort to follow the Shelter-In-Place order with greater fidelity. Moving forward, the district will open the meal distribution sites two days a week: Monday and Thursday.

Read more: http://www.desotoisd.org/news/what_s_new/de_i_s_d_meal_distribution_update
text:
Due to the district’s holiday closure, no Grab and Go Meals will be served Friday, April 10 nor Monday, April 13.

As noted, that the 75115 zip code is among the highest in the DFW area experiencing confirmed cases of COVID-19, we want to minimize the number of times our students and families are leaving their homes to access district-provided meals. We hope that this reduction will assist the county in its effort to follow the Shelter-In-Place order with greater fidelity. Moving forward, the district will open the meal distribution sites two days a week: Monday and Thursday.

Read more: http://www.desotoisd.org/news/what_s_new/de_i_s_d_meal_distribution_update

In observance and Good Friday and Easter, DeSoto ISD will be closed on Friday, April 10 and Monday, April 13, for a student & staff holiday as previously scheduled in the 2019-2020 Academic Calendar. The district will resume operating virtually on Tuesday, April 14, 2020.

Meals will not be distributed at our meal sites on Friday, April 10 or Monday, April 14.
text:
In observance and Good Friday and Easter, DeSoto ISD will be closed on Friday, April 10 and Monday, April 13, for a student & staff holiday as previously scheduled in the 2019-2020 Academic Calendar. The district will resume operating virtually on Tuesday, April 14, 2020.

Meals will not be distributed at our meal sites on Friday, April 10 or Monday, April 14.

post_text:
Due to the district’s holiday closure, no Grab and Go Meals will be served Friday, April 10 nor Monday, April 13.

As noted, that the 75115 zip code is among the highest in the DFW area experiencing confirmed cases of COVID-19, we want to minimize the number of times our students and families are leaving their homes to access district-provided meals. We hope that this reduction will assist the county in its effort to follow the Shelter-In-Place order with greater fidelity. Moving forward, the district will open the meal distribution sites two days a week: Monday and Thursday.

Read more: http://www.desotoisd.org/news/what_s_new/de_i_s_d_meal_distribution_update

post_text:
In DeSoto ISD, we are extremely lucky to have a hard-working, passionate group of assistant principals who tirelessly serve their campuses and the district with esteem and pride. In honor of National Assistant Principal Week, we celebrate Ms. Jannie Nelson of The Meadows Elementary.

Ms. Nelson is described as a partner in educational leadership at the campus by her principal. "Ms. Nelson's contributions are invaluable to the daily work and success of the campus. From her joyous and energetic disposition, to her background in special education and restorative discipline practices, PBIS, and English/Language Arts expertise, she has been a creative and vitally important asset to our campus. Her spirit and love for our students and staff has been 'infectious."

#APWeek20 #ThankaDeISDAP

In DeSoto ISD, we are extremely lucky to have a hard working, passionate group of assistant principals who tirelessly serve their campuses and the district with esteem and pride. In honor of National Assistant Principal Week, we will continue this social celebration with Ms. Verlean West, DeSoto High School (11th grade House Principal).

Her central focus is to enhance the learning experience for 11th grade students and to support our elective teachers. Her principal, Mr. Shon Joseph, also shared that Mrs. West has been instrumental in executing the campus testing plans. "During this time, she makes herself available to support around the clock. The work never stops and Mrs. West answers the call." #APWeek20 #ThankaDeISDAP

post_text:
In DeSoto ISD, we are extremely lucky to have a hard working, passionate group of assistant principals who tirelessly serve their campuses and the district with esteem and pride. In honor of National Assistant Principal Week, we will continue this social celebration with Dr. Malikah Graves of Cockrell Hill Elementary.

Assistant Principal Dr. Malikah Graves is described by her principal as one whose contributions to the campus are definitely aligned to a portion of the famous quote by William A. Foster. “Quality is never an accident; it is always the result of high intention, sincere effort, intelligent direction and skillful execution; it represents the wise choice of many alternatives.” Dr. Graves is intentional in supporting the work of educating students, maintaining discipline, and building quality relationships. #APWeek20 #ThankaDeISDAP

In observance and Good Friday and Easter, DeSoto ISD will be closed on Friday, April 10 and Monday, April 13, for a student & staff holiday as previously scheduled in the 2019-2020 Academic Calendar. The district will resume operating virtually on Tuesday, April 14, 2020.

Meals will not be distributed at our meal sites on Friday, April 10 or Monday, April 14.
text:
In observance and Good Friday and Easter, DeSoto ISD will be closed on Friday, April 10 and Monday, April 13, for a student & staff holiday as previously scheduled in the 2019-2020 Academic Calendar. The district will resume operating virtually on Tuesday, April 14, 2020.

Meals will not be distributed at our meal sites on Friday, April 10 or Monday, April 14.

post_text:
The Eagle Advantage Child Development Center teachers are creating learning opportunities for our students. Parents receive lesson plans weekly via email that address cognitive learning, social and emotional development, gross motor skills, and art activities. Also, parents are able to contact their child’s teacher via phone, text or email if they have questions about the weekly lessons.

These EACDC students represent the infant room and 2-year-old classes.

#TOGETHERWEWILL #EACDCROCKS

DeSoto ISD
April 6 at 11:13 AM ·

Throughout the month of April, we will be hosting Town Hall Tuesdays. Each Tuesday of this month we’ll be live online discussing important topics as we navigate through this unprecedented time.

If you have a question, you would like answered during one of the Town Halls, submit them at www.desotoisd.org/TownHallTuesday

Topics include:

April 7: District Response to CoVid-19 and AALP
April 14: Principals Talk Back
April 21: Mental Health and Wellness during CoVid-19
April 28: DeSoto ISD CoVid-19 Student Perspectives with the Superintendent's Student Advisory Council

post_text:
In DeSoto ISD, teachers and leaders believe that learning can take place anytime and anywhere.

While the district’s campuses closed mid-March and remain closed indefinitely during this COVID-19 global pandemic, DeSoto ISD continues to provide virtual educational experiences and resources through the Anytime, Anywhere Learning Plan.

“Anytime, Anywhere Learning is providing access to high-quality learning experiences for every single child through the creativity, collaboration, and solution-orientation of our teachers and leaders,” Chief Academic Officer Celeste Barretto said. “We seek to remove barriers to those learning experiences for every child, and to move beyond the bounds of the brick and mortar school building or the limitations of the clock. It means blended and tech-free learning opportunities for every child, anytime, anywhere.”

Read More: http://desotoisd.ss10.sharpschool.com/news/what_s_new/DeSotoIISD_offers_anytime_anywhere_learning

post_text:
A message from Superintendent of Schools, D'Andre Weaver, Ph.D.:

I hope you are safe and healthy in these challenging times. What we are experiencing today is certainly not what any of us had planned for our students nor for our community. Please know how grateful I am for your continued support and care for one another.

I am especially grateful for the healthcare workers and their courage and dedication to keeping us safe during this public health concern. Thank you to everyone, across a number of professional fields and industries, who are selflessly serving on the frontlines of this pandemic and for the sacrifices that you and your families are making to fight COVID-19.

Read more: http://www.desotoisd.org/cms/One.aspx?portalId=165774&pageId=23689951

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iELcsgA33H0&feature=emb_logo

“This learning is better for me because it’s less distractions than in the classroom. I can contact my teachers when I need to. It’s like an online tutoring. I’m excelling more and I’m really able to get my work done.” said DeSoto High School sophomore, Desjéa Franklin.

Students and parents, we would like you to share how your anytime, anywhere learning is going? Let us know in the comments or email us at INFO@DeSotoISD.org

post_text:
The 2020 Census is more than a population count. It's an opportunity to shape your community's future. The 2020 Census counts could mean millions of dollars to DeSoto ISD!

The census provides critical data that lawmakers, business owners, teachers, and many others use to provide daily services, products, and support for you and your community. Every year, billions of dollars in federal funding go to hospitals, fire departments, schools, roads, and other resources based on census data.

The results of the census also determine the number of seats each state will have in the U.S. House of Representatives, and they are used to draw congressional and state legislative districts.

YOU COUNT!
ANSWER THE CENSUS TODAY!
WWW.2020CENSUS.GOV
ESPANOL 844-468-2020
ENGLISH 844-330-2020

Chartwells and the DeSoto ISD Child Nutrition Department are opening THREE more meal-serving sites!

Starting Wednesday, April 1st, Ruby Young, Cockrell Hill, and Woodridge will be open for service. The Food Truck will stay at Amber Terrace for Breakfast and Lunch.

For a map of the open sites and times, go to https://desotoisd.nutrislice.com/menu/

Sites and Times of Operation:
The Meadows Elementary: 9 AM - 1 PM M-F
Frank Moates Elementary: 9 AM - 1 PM M-F
DeSoto High School- Freshman Campus Side: 9 AM - 1 PM M-F

Starting Wednesday, April 1st:
NEW PERMANENT LOCATION- Amber Terrace DECA- Food Truck: 9 AM - 1 PM M-F
NEW PERMANENT LOCATION- Woodridge Elementary: 9 AM - 1 PM M-F
NEW- Ruby Young Elementary: 9 AM - 1 PM M-F
NEW- Cockrell Hill Elementary: 9 AM - 1 PM M-F

The DeSoto ISD School Board will hold a special called meeting at 5:30 p.m. on Monday, March 30, 2020, to discuss possibly moving the May 2 election to November 3.

Out of an abundance of caution and as a precautionary measure in response to concerns related to the Coronavirus pandemic, this meeting will be conducted by videoconference or telephone call.

💻The meeting can be viewed on DeISD's website here: http://ow.ly/xTJ850z01Bb

📝Agenda: http://ow.ly/VMrY50z01Bc

Students in grades six through 12 were able to pick up district-provided devices at DeSoto High School after receiving a special check out code via email.

The district will issue devices through 4pm today.

Thank you to our Technology staff for your hard work to ensure students have the tools and resources they need to continue learning at home.

#togetherwewill #DeSotoStrong

post_text:
Hi DeSoto ISD Eagles! You’ve been patiently awaiting news about long-term plan for distance learning for this semester while you have worked HARD on your week 1 and week 2 distance learning assignments! We’ve got a stellar plan to meet the needs of our students with tech and tech-free assignments, flexible instructional methods to allow students, families, and district employees the flexibility to adjust to life in response to a global pandemic, and a plan that ensures access to high-quality learning for students!

Students, we have posted learning plans for the week of March 30, 2020. Find the plans at our DeSoto ISD Distance Learning website. (www.DeSotoISD.org/DistanceLearning) Students and families with questions should contact their child’s teachers directly.

post_text: Child Nutrition Update:
shared_text:
Texas Education Agency
March 26 at 9:17 AM ·

UPDATE: For our participating MealFinder schools, here is a quick update from the Texas Department of Agriculture - While schools are not quite ready to begin the parent-only free meal pickup, TDA is working to make that happen as quickly as possible. Please check your district’s website for details…thank you!

Great news! The Texas Department of Ag. has received a waiver that allows parents to pick up free school meals without their children present. We hope this change helps more families.

To find a meal distribution site near you, visit: txschools.gov #txed

🦅#TogetherWeWill is more relevant and present during this unprecedented time than ever before. We recognize the power that lies in working as a community with a shared vision, focus, and goal. 💚

🦅Let’s show others the strength, pride, and unity of our DeSoto ISD community and that we are all in this together by expressing appreciation and support to our teachers, parents, and students. Please take a moment to share encouraging or motivational words using this tagline, We Are DeSoto ISD and Together, We Will!

📸📱Everyone is welcome to share a 15-30 second video message. Please submit all content to info@desotoisd.org or inbox us Facebook by Tuesday, March 31.

A scholarship opportunity for DeSoto High School students:

The Pearls of the Ivy Foundation is offering scholarships to provide financial assistance to exemplary high school students who are accepted by an accredited college or university. Each scholarship has specific criteria and essay requirements. The deadline extension for all applications is May 1, 2020. Please refer to scholarship application instructions online at: https://pearlsoftheivyfoundation.org/

E-mail completed applications to:
PIFscholars@gmail.com

DeSoto ISD is enacting a district-wide closure of schools and offices to encourage social distancing measures for the health and safety of our community in response to the novel coronavirus (COVID-19). We have come together to create a plan for student learning and a collection of resources for families to accommodate our immediate and indefinite closure for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year.
Please click the link to access the learning plans.

post_text:
As we close out this first week of designing our New Normal in DeSoto ISD, I want to offer a few words of encouragement.

What we are currently experiencing is unprecedented and there is no framework or point of reference for the journey we are navigating. You may be feeling fear, concern or uncertainty.

You are not alone.

DeSoto ISD is right here with you, and we are committed to fulfilling our role of service and support in this community.

As a parent of two DeSoto ISD students, I understand how difficult these dramatic changes have been for our families, and we are working to ensure that we have addressed as many concerns as we can related to the district’s extended closure.

Read more: http://www.desotoisd.org/cms/One.aspx?portalId=165774&pageId=23637443

Out of an abundance of caution and as a result of developments related to the Coronavirus pandemic, DeSoto ISD has postponed the Katherine Johnson admissions testing that was originally scheduled for March 21 and March 28.

You can expect to receive more information about the rescheduled KJ admissions testing by early April.

While we recognize this could cause an inconvenience for some, the health and safety of our community is our utmost concern.

If you have any questions, please email Principal Angela Batiste at Angela.Batiste@desotoisd.org.

http://desotoisd.ss10.sharpschool.com/news/what_s_new/k_j_t_m_a_application_test_postponed

post_text: Students & Families: If you have questions about the content of the distance learning plan or require instructional support that is not technology hardware related, please reach out to your child’s teachers directly via email. If you and your child’s teacher are unable to resolve the issue, you may forward your question and the communication thread to desotoisddistancelearning@gmail.com. We will do our best to respond to and resolve your issue within 24 hours.
text: Students & Families: If you have questions about the content of the distance learning plan or require instructional support that is not technology hardware related, please reach out to your child’s teachers directly via email. If you and your child’s teacher are unable to resolve the issue, you may forward your question and the communication thread to desotoisddistancelearning@gmail.com. We will do our best to respond to and resolve your issue within 24 hours.

post_text:
Starting Monday, Mar 16, free meals will be available to children ages 18 and under at the following distribution sites:

-The Meadows ES

-Moates ES

-DHS- Freshman Side

-Woodridge ES & Amber Terrace DDC - Food Truck

The packaged meals will be distributed directly to vehicles at the above-listed sites from 9am to 1pm Monday through Friday.

Please note, all children must be present to receive a meal.

Additionally, a food truck will be at Woodridge from 9 am until 10:45 am. It will then transition to Amber Terrace to serve meals from 11am until 1pm.

More information will go out to district families and staff via email.

For updates and developments, visit www.DeSotoISD.org/Coronavirus.

Please direct questions or comments by email to INFO@DeSotoISD.org.

post_text:
Genesis of Dallas continues to salute DeSoto ISD Teachers of the Month with a 30-day free use of a new Genesis G-70! The Genesis G-70 is a 4-door compact executive sedan designed to compete with vehicles such as the Audi A4, the BMW 3 Series, Mercedes-Benz C-Class and Infiniti Q50.

The teacher of the month for March is Channon Payton, a 6th, 7th,8th inclusion and Resource Teacher from McCowan Middle School. Mrs. Payton has been in education for 7 years and on this campus for the entire time. A graduate of Langston University with a degree in Psychology and University of Central Oklahoma with a Master’s in Education, Mrs. Payton chose education because during her prior career as a Juvenile Probation Officer, she knew that she had more to offer and wanted to have a positive impact on the lives she touched.

You are invited to apply to be Mayor for a Day in the City of DeSoto on Tuesday, March 17. The purpose of this program is to help DeSoto ISD students understand how a city really operates and understand the rigor and rewards of being a mayor.

Application packets and brochures are available from your campus counselors or you may email info@desotoisd.org using MAYOR FOR A DAY as the subject line to request a packet.

post_text:
EarthX, a non-profit organization founded by Trammel S. Crow, provides the Omniglobe to several districts throughout the school year. Omniglobe allows students to view a variety of 3D spherical representations on a wide range of educational content that includes the solar system, geologic changes of the earth, climate and weather, fractals and much more. Omniglobe’s first stop is Katherine Johnson Technology Magnet Academy; the system will be displayed at several other schools in the coming weeks. Thanks to EarthX and Trammel S. Crow, students will be able to engage in learning experiences in an innovative environment.

Link to EarthX: https://earthx.org/

DeSoto ISD added 9 new photos.
February ·

During the regular meeting of the DeSoto ISD School Board, the West Middle School JROTC students presented the colors and five DHS students were recognized for their national choir selections. DeISD Vice President DeAndrea Fleming was recognized for her selection as the #TABSE School Board Trustee of the Year and the district shared proclamations for National Counselors Week, Career and Technology month, and Black History Month. Students from the Curtistene S. McCowan Middle School band performed two selections and the theater students shared a series of tributes to African American history. The district also closed the recognitions with a brief resolution and moment of silence in honor of NASA Mathematician and campus namesake, Katherine Johnson.

DeSoto ISD added 21 new photos.
February 21 at 1:07 PM ·

The DeSoto West Middle School hosted their Black History Program last evening in grand fashion. The DeSoto West Choir sang Lift Every Voice and Sing to open the performance, followed by poems and performances by the DeSoto West Middle School Band. Parents were also wowed by the performance of the visiting West Main Elementary Tiger Steppers from Lancaster ISD along with an astounding performance by the DeSoto West Middle School Cheer and Dance team. The evening culminated beautifully with a three-act play written by a former DeSoto East Middle School student titled, The Truth will Set you Free.

shared_text:
DeSoto ISD added 3 new photos — at Dallas College Cedar Valley Campus.
February · Lancaster, TX ·

Fourteen students from the DeSoto Independent School District were among the more than 130 participants in the third National CTE Signing Day event at Cedar Valley College. The event allowed students to publicly declare their intent to obtain an industry work-ready certification alongside their #DCCCD degree at Cedar Valley College.

During the event, the students had the opportunity to hear from District 30 U.S Representative Eddie Bernice Johnson, DCCCD trustees-Charletta Rogers Compton and Wesley Jameson, DCCCD Chancellor Joe May and CVC President Dr. Joseph Seabrooks and a keynote from Mark Hays of DCCCD Workforce program.

Additionally, students enjoyed an information session with Kubata to learn what it will take to be successful as an employee in their organization. The representatives from Kubata also gave swag bags to all of our students in the session.

DHS students signed letters of intent in the Industry, Manufacturing & Construction Health Sciences and the Arts Humanities, Communications and Design pathways. #Soaringbeyond #CVCONLINE #NC3Skills

Ash’a Thompson, a 5-10 guard, has been a cornerstone in the rise of the Lady Eagles under Coach Andrea Robinson. They are prepared to make a fourth-straight playoff appearance together, with a goal of winning one more game in the postseason than last year, when they finished as the Class 6A state runners-up to Converse Judson with a narrow 49-46 loss.

post_text:
Andrew Brown, a senior, is a recipient of a $1,000 College Board Opportunity Scholarship. Open to all students, these scholarships recognize students for their efforts to plan and prepare for college. They can be applied to tuition, fees, books and other relevant undergraduate educational expenses at two or four-year institutions. Students are eligible for Opportunity Scholarships by completing actions such as building a college list, practicing for the SAT, applying to colleges, and completing and submitting the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA).

We are extremely excited for Mr. Brown! Please join us in congratulating this phenomenal Eagle! #EagleProud 🦅
#SoaringBeyond

****AP Coordinator Charla McClure and Associate Principal Kristi Primus also pictured.

This weekend, students from West Middle school shared their artistic talents by painting the athletic logo at DeSoto Police Department!

But that's just the start! The DeSoto ISD Fine Arts students are teaming up with the DeSoto Police Department to transform the police department lobby into an art gallery celebrating Black History Month!!

Come drop by the DeSoto Police Department Feb 24-28 and vote for the top 3 young artists in DeSoto! The winners will be awarded a gift card by the DPD, and the winners will be recognized during the March 3 City Council meeting.

post_text:
The DeSoto ISD Calendar Committee has developed two calendar options for consideration for the 2020-2021 school year. In both calendar options, students have 170 instructional days and exceed the state required 75,600 minutes of instruction. However, you will see in calendar option 2, the district plans to adopt a bi-weekly half-day model that incorporates alternative learning experiences for the students of the DeSoto Independent School District. Our rationale is that expanding learning outside the four walls of traditional pedagogical practices provides opportunities for students to grow as learners and acquire critical 21st-century skills they might not access in their current classroom setting. We believe this model has the potential to yield multiple positive outcomes for students and staff.

Learn more about both calendar options and vote at. www.DeSotoISD.org/2021Calendar

Past meeting topics included the secondary course catalogs, calendar options for the next school year and the district improvement plans. The next meeting is scheduled February 12 at the Belt Line Conference Center (located behind the Administration Building) from 6 pm to 8 pm. See you there!

post_text: DeSoto ISD celebrates Black History Month! James Mercer Langston Hughes was an American poet, social activist, novelist, playwright, and columnist from Joplin, Missouri. He moved to New York City as a young man, where he made his career.He was one of the earliest innovators of the then-new literary art form called jazz poetry. Hughes is best known as a leader of the Harlem Renaissance in New York City. He famously wrote about the period that "the negro was in vogue", which was later paraphrased as "when Harlem was in vogue". #RememberEducateCelebrate https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=inP76rkYUso

YOUTUBE.COM

This morning, DeSoto Independent School District hosted student-athletes and their families at the annual National Signing Day event! This year’s class of DeSoto ISD student-athletes signed athletic scholarship-based commitments to the colleges and universities at which they will continue their athletic pursuits while also working towards college degrees.

Students were introduced by their coaches and received words of encouragement from the athletic director and other district leaders present.

Congratulations to all students and their families! Soar HIGH!

post_text:
Genesis of Dallas continues to salute DeSoto ISD Teachers of the Month with a 30-day free use of a new Genesis G-70! DeSoto West Middle School is the school for February and their Teacher of the Month is Sgt. Don Brookins, Junior Cadet Corp teacher. Sgt. Brookins has been in education for 17 years and on the DeSoto West campus for the duration of his teaching career. Sgt. Brookins earned his degree and teaching certificate while serving in the United States Army. Sgt Brookins served 26 years before retiring as Sgt. First Class. He chose education because of his strong desire to help young people become better citizens. Principal Shana Hawthorne applauds the selection of Sgt. Brookins because he goes over and beyond the call of duty. Thank you, Sgt. Brookins.

The Genesis G-70 is a 4-door compact executive sedan designed to compete with vehicles such as the Audi A4, the BMW 3 Series, Mercedes-Benz C-Class and Infiniti Q50. Thank you, Genesis of Dallas for your continued support of our teachers.

post_text:
DHS A Capella Choir members Alexandria Ellison and Juliana Simonfalvi have been named to the Texas All State Honors Choir for 2020! This is the third year that Juliana has earned All State recognition!

The All State competition process began in September 2019, advancing through District, Region, Pre-Area and finally Area Auditions which were held in Waco Texas on January 11, 2020. Juliana placed first chair Alto and Alex placed in the Treble Honors Choir which will be performing at the TMEA Clinic/Convention, February 15, 2020 @ the Convention Center in San Antonio.

All-State is the highest honor a Texas music student can receive. 1,780 students are selected through a process that begins with over 68,000 students from around the state vying for this honor to perform in one of 15 ensembles (bands, orchestras, and choirs). All-State students participate in three days of rehearsals directed by nationally recognized conductors during the annual state TMEA Clinic/Convention February 2020. Their performances before thousands of attendees bring this extraordinary event to a close.

post_text: In DeSoto ISD, we aim to keep our learning environment healthy for our students and staff. We are amid a strong flu season in Texas and want to remind you to help prevent the flu and the spread of it by being attentive to your child and following the preventative measures. Please NOTE that if a student has a fever, the student can not return to school until the fever is gone for at least 24 hours.

You are invited to apply to be Mayor for a Day in the City of DeSoto on Tuesday, March 17. The purpose of this program is to help DeSoto ISD students understand how a city really operates and understand the rigor and rewards of being a mayor.

Thousands of educators, alumni, parents, community supporters, business people and elected officials have made significant contributions to the development and improvement of DeSoto ISD. DeSoto High School has graduated thousands of people with rewarding careers, individuals who touch the lives of others - from artists, elected officials, and CEOs, to doctors, lawyers and entrepreneurs.

DeSoto ISD added 36 new photos.
January 24 at 4:42 PM ·

Dr. Weaver updated various stakeholders at the annual state of the district luncheon this week. The district’s superintendent updated attendees on the district’s FOCUS plan. Assuring community members that we are focused on a new direction of the district. The event was catered by our very own DeSoto High School Culinary students. The flower arrangements were crafted by students in the floral design program at DHS. Also, there was a performance by the DeSoto East Middle school Tenor/Bass choir and DHS Junior; Taylor Dunn performed the national anthem, while the DHS JROTC presented the colors. The event concluded with DHS Senior; Tiffany Kalu being recognized by the DeSoto Chamber of Commerce as this month’s Student of the Month.

DeSoto ISD’s Virtual Town Hall.
DeSoto Independent School District hosted its second Virtual Town Hall on Friday, January 24, 2020 via Facebook LIVE with panelists including Superintendent of Schools, D’Andre Weaver, Ph.D, Chief of Human Resources, Mia Stroy, Chief of Student Support Services, Natalia Fernandez along with students from DeSoto High School and moderated by Director of Communications, Tiffanie Blackmon-Jones.

During the live event, Stroy and Fernandez discussed various initiatives their respective departments are working on to propel the district forward and would allow better opportunities for students and staff.

Read more: http://www.desotoisd.org/news/what_s_new/district_hosts_second_virtual_town_hall

post_text:
DESOTO - The Infinite Scholars Program invites Desoto ISD parents and students in grades six to twelve to attend the 11th Annual Free College - Scholarship fair on Saturday, January 25 from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. at Community Baptist Church located at 115 W. Belt Line Road in DeSoto, Texas.

While there is no registration requirement to attend the fair and all middle and high school students are welcomed, the seniors will have chance to compete for the $5 million scholarships available at the event when they bring at least ten (10) packets of the following information to share with the colleges/universities awarding scholarships:

• Transcript,
• ACT/SAT scores
• Course schedule for the senior year
• Student resume
• Personal statement / essay
• School Profile
• Recommendation letters (3)

Learn More at :http://www.desotoisd.org/news/what_s_new/desoto_isd_students_invited_to_scholarship_fair

shared_text:
DeSoto ISD added 9 new photos — at DeSoto High School.
January 15 at 4:47 PM · DeSoto, TX ·

Students from the DeSoto ISD elementary and middle school campuses competed in the UIL A+ Academics competition on Saturday, January 11. They competed in the following categories: Science, Mathematics, Spelling, Storytelling, Number Sense, Modern Oratory, Oral Reading, Social Studies, Creative Writing, and Editorial Writing.

Participants who earned first through sixth place were recognized in an awards ceremony following the competition. Alternates were also recognized for their participation. The district winner for the elementary academic competition is Katherine Johnson Technology Magnet Academy. The district winner for the middle school academic competition is McCowan Middle School.

During the event, HAKing Innovation - a nonprofit organization focused on STEM - provided opportunities for students to learn about electronic circuits and 3D printing. Julie Blasingame, a retired DeSoto ISD teacher, taught students and parents how to play chess. #SoaringBeyond #TogetherWeWill
text:
DeSoto ISD added 9 new photos — at DeSoto High School.
January 15 at 4:47 PM · DeSoto, TX ·

Students from the DeSoto ISD elementary and middle school campuses competed in the UIL A+ Academics competition on Saturday, January 11. They competed in the following categories: Science, Mathematics, Spelling, Storytelling, Number Sense, Modern Oratory, Oral Reading, Social Studies, Creative Writing, and Editorial Writing.

Participants who earned first through sixth place were recognized in an awards ceremony following the competition. Alternates were also recognized for their participation. The district winner for the elementary academic competition is Katherine Johnson Technology Magnet Academy. The district winner for the middle school academic competition is McCowan Middle School.

During the event, HAKing Innovation - a nonprofit organization focused on STEM - provided opportunities for students to learn about electronic circuits and 3D printing. Julie Blasingame, a retired DeSoto ISD teacher, taught students and parents how to play chess. #SoaringBeyond #TogetherWeWill

post_text:
🗣 An exciting announcement from Superintendent of Schools, D’Andre Weaver, Ph.D.

Congratulations to students at Katherine Johnson Technology Magnet Academy and Curtistene S. McCowan Middle School. They are the elementary & middle school winners of the UIL A+ Academics competition taking place this past weekend.

Excellent job, students!! 🎉

post_text:
For the February Fourth Friday concert/event, the DeSoto Arts Commission is pleased to present the Dallas Black Dance Theater on Friday, February 28, 2020 at 7 pm at the DeSoto High School - Fred Nickels Auditorium, located at 600 Eagle Drive. Before the historic dance company takes the stage, there will also be a special performance by the DeSoto High School A Capella Choir. This outstanding evening of entertainment is underwritten by the DeSoto Arts Commission, City of DeSoto and DeSoto ISD and, as a result, we can offer special pricing. General Admission tickets are just $10 each. All students and seniors 60+ may attend the performance for just $5 per person.

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/desoto-arts-commission-presents-the-dallas-black-dance-theatre-tickets-88864834111?aff=efbeventtix&fbclid=IwAR0nkvRddIMlz2SGSjDTWaYGIS6MorositwN1LpG0rP7Ip-FSPoWyvYfeNQ

The DeSoto Independent School District Board of Trustees serves as an oversight committee for the operations and success of its school community. In order to ensure that the actions of the Board were guided by practical and measurable targets, the Board began work to identify and establish goals and operating procedures that would serve as the compass by which to make decisions on behalf of DeSoto ISD students and families.

➡️Read More: http://www.desotoisd.org/news/what_s_new/de_soto_i_s_d_board_of_trustees_establishes_goals

shared_text:
DeSoto ISD added 10 new photos.
January 6 at 5:27 PM ·

The teacher of the month for Ruby Young Elementary School is Mr. Marcus Ware, Kinder-5th Grade Behavior Intervention Classroom teacher. Mr. Ware has been in education for two years in DeSoto ISD and on this campus for two years.

Mr. Ware graduated from East Texas State University in Commerce, Texas with a degree in Business Administration. He chose education because he noticed the varying needs of children as he had the opportunity to work with children via other organizational affiliations.

Principal Duren applauded the selection of Mr.Ware because he goes above and beyond the call of duty when it comes to supporting our students throughout the building. Students and parents alike respect his degree of willingness to work with our students along with his extremely caring attitude and concern for the overall well-being of every child on our campus. He is indeed a great professional and highly regarded by all stakeholders at Ruby Young ES.

Help your child find their passion and work toward success!

Start with a dream, leave with a future! The pathway to success starts in DeSoto Independent School District’s magnet and innovative programs. Powered by the Academy for Academic Enhancement and Excellence – A2E2.

DeSoto ISD offers specialized magnet program choices to students in grades K-12 with the goal of providing enriching and innovative learning experiences that align with your student’s talents, interests, and academic and career goals. Help your child find their passion and work toward success!

Apply now and learn more about our magnet programs at www.desotoisda2e2.org
#DeISDa2e2

Apply now and learn more about our magnet programs at www.desotoisda2e2.org

post_text: Santa made an early visit to Moates Elementary this morning thanks to the Glenn Heights Fire Department - GHFD! Since the sleigh was getting prepped for next week, Santa came in on a fire engine. The toys are being packed for delivery as the elves on the shelf continue to provide updates, so today Santa passed out candy canes to the students. Thanks City of Glenn Heights, TX for your continued support of DeSoto ISD!

post_text:
The DeSoto ISD Board Meeting kicked off with many celebrations and recognitions highlighting the great things happening around the district:

-DeSoto Welcomes New Chief Financial Officer

-Student Achievement in Goal Setting

-The District student holiday greeting card contest winners were announced.

-100% of the DHS Class of 2020 completed the Dallas County Promise Pledge & college applications.

-The DeSoto ISD Energy Dept. announced campuses that helped the district save on electric costs.

-DHS Band Director was recognized for being a finalist and regional winner of the William P. Foster Music Excellence Award.

Another notable moment, the East Middle School Tenor Choir performed an impressive arrangement of several holiday classics prior to the meeting starting.

shared_text:
DeSoto ISD added 2 new photos.
December 12, 2019 at 6:27 AM ·

DeSoto High School students joined other students from districts in the Best Southwest area to participate in the Pipelines to Possibilities’ College Explosion. The program that was founded by four Dallas County Judges is designed to help students live their dreams, make positive life decisions and become leaders in society. The students had the chance to hear the journey of one of the 1988 Carter High School Football Championship team members who made some costly decisions and changed the course of his life. Also, they had the chance to explore some Greek lettered service organizations and talk with representatives from colleges and universities such as UT-Austin, Paul Quinn College, UNT, UNT- Dallas, Texas A&M University and Grambling University and Texas A&M Commerce.

shared_text:
DeSoto ISD added 41 new photos.
December 11, 2019 at 3:33 PM ·

25 DeSoto High School 🦅students were surprised to learn they are recipients of scholarships from Texas Southern University with a combined total of $206,000, or $824,000 over the next four years. The university offers scholarships that fall into four categories: Regents, Presidents, Genesis I & Genesis II and range from $4,000 to $14,000. However, these students received awards in the top three categories. The scholarships are also renewable to the recipients on an annual basis as long as the students meet grade point average requirements. ➡️Read More: http://www.desotoisd.org/news/what_s_new/d_h_s_seniors_awarded_scholarships_from_t_s_u

DeSoto ISD added 31 new photos.
December 11, 2019 at 12:07 PM ·

Last night, the DeSoto ISD ACE program hosted Dinner Tonight Junior at DeSoto High School. Students, along with their parents and/or guardians were able to learn about fresh and healthy meal options from the Texas A&M Agrilife Extension and Prairie View A&M University. Attendees enjoyed a live demonstration of recipes with the help of a few DeSoto ISD elementary students. Thanks to all that attended this exciting event.

post_text:
Today, there was an alleged threat made against DeSoto High School. The threat was reported by a DHS student who found a handwritten note in one of the restrooms on the campus. The campus and district administrators immediately responded to the concern and contacted local law enforcement and the district’s security team to resolve this threat with minimal disruption to the school environment. The investigation is still in progress and we will provide an update as more information becomes available.

In an effort to address security concerns, the campus administration will operate with heightened security measures until the start of the winter break.
text:
Today, there was an alleged threat made against DeSoto High School. The threat was reported by a DHS student who found a handwritten note in one of the restrooms on the campus. The campus and district administrators immediately responded to the concern and contacted local law enforcement and the district’s security team to resolve this threat with minimal disruption to the school environment. The investigation is still in progress and we will provide an update as more information becomes available.

In an effort to address security concerns, the campus administration will operate with heightened security measures until the start of the winter break.

DeSoto ISD added 34 new photos — at DeSoto High School.
December 2019 · DeSoto, TX ·

The DeSoto ISD Eagle Parent Summit, held at DeSoto High School today, provided parents with informational and educational resources on attendance, truancy, college and career readiness, social media and social emotional learning. The goal of this event was to increase parent engagement and student achievement, improve the school and community collaboration and promote safety. This summit was organized by the DeSoto ISD Truancy and Attendance team with support from the DHS Campus Administration. #togetherwewill

The DeSoto ISD Eagle Parent Summit, held at DeSoto High School today, provided parents with informational and educational resources on attendance, truancy, college and career readiness, social media and social emotional learning. The goal of this event was to increase parent engagement and student achievement, improve the school and community collaboration and promote safety. This summit was organized by the DeSoto ISD Truancy and Attendance team with support from the DHS Campus Administration. #togetherwewill

Curtistene S. McCowan Middle School student, Jordynn West, was honored by the City of Glenn Heights Mayor, Harry A. Garrett, and members of the City Council at their regular board meeting on Tuesday, December 3, 2019.

The 8th grader received a proclamation from the city for her outstanding accomplishments in academics and competing nationally in Track & Field.

The proclamation signed by Mayor Garrett reads in part, “It has been brought to the attention of the City of Glenn Heights that Jordynn West, a student at McCowan Middle School, exhibits astounding scholastic and athletic abilities, which have earned her national recognition and elite awards.”

Read More ➡️ http://ow.ly/LSDz50xs6jz

shared_text:
DeSoto ISD added 11 new photos — with Genesis of Dallas at DeSoto High School.
December 4, 2019 at 12:48 PM · DeSoto, TX ·

Genesis of Dallas continues to salute DeSoto ISD Teachers of the Month with a 30-day free use of a new Genesis G-70! The Genesis G-70 is a 4-door compact executive sedan designed to compete with vehicles such as the Audi A4, the BMW 3 Series, Mercedes-Benz C-Class and Infiniti Q50.

This month’s school is DeSoto High School and the teacher of the month is Fojulia O’Neal. This Grambling State University graduate holds a Bachelor’s degree in Biology and has been an educator for 8 years, five of them at DHS.

Her specialty is teaching Science with what has been described as a tireless passion. Ms. O’Neal regards her rewarding relationships with students as the top of her accomplishments. She maintains that being flexible and fun loving with her students enables them to become motivated learners.
